items.title: Relative Paths to all for use with a reverse proxy
items.body:
Is there any way to set the base url -- I am trying to run this behind a proxy and need to run it in a subpath (ex: /rqdashboard).

Maybe a simple inject of the base href tag could help (https://html.com/attributes/base-href/) and getting the value from an ENV or config value?

items.title: Bring date and time to a uniform view (use local time zone everywhere)
Job status not updates as its should
items.body: Where is the problem with deleting jobs from the non-queued-or-failed registers and invalid status on the single job view page

items.title: Make rq instance selector inactive if used only one instance
how can i access a protected redis server?
items.body:
hi :)

my redis server started with `["redis-server", "--appendonly", "yes", "--requirepass", "${REDIS_PWD}"]`. so it required a password.

and i do not know how to pass my password to dashboard. 

```
- RQ_DASHBOARD_REDIS_URL=redis://<redis:6379>
- RQ_DASHBOARD_USERNAME=rq
- RQ_DASHBOARD_PASSWORD=password
```

username and password here will be only used for dashboard itself right? 

I did not find a correct way in README. and what should i do?

items.title: Set multiple RQ connections with Docker Compose?
items.body: I was having some issues spinning up 2 dashboards (through docker compose) so after reading through some issues I found that I can pass an array of Redis connections to connect to them. How would you do that through Docker Compose? I don't think arrays are supported in .env files.

items.title: Consider reworking the rq lib job structure.
Revise deleting jobs mechanism
Use instance number in APIs
items.body:
There is need to keep backend stateful as It is now.
We can change instance ID on frontend and then pass It to all API calls.
This way we can remove endpoint for changing instance.

Selection alert not fading properly
How to empty failed registry of given queue?
items.body:
I'm using the newest version of RQ dashboard from GitHub repo (cause it has very useful feature of displaying all registers of all queues unlike version from PyPi). But in comparison with previous version, this does not have a button to empty fail jobs from queue, despite of this button exists in queued registry:
![Screenshot from 2019-11-20 18-04-01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22215769/69250959-aac74080-0bc1-11ea-98f5-244331f0ecc3.png)
![Screenshot from 2019-11-20 18-04-41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22215769/69250978-b450a880-0bc1-11ea-937a-30351d72c395.png)
How to enable this functionality or perform this action in other way?

items.title: How to use multiple Redis connections without changing source code?
items.body:
I want to monitor multiple RQ instances on 5 Redis clusters. So i have 5 Redis servers and want to switching between them to observe.
I found this: https://github.com/Parallels/rq-dashboard/issues/128
If I fully understand author, for multiple RQ instances usage, I have to fork repository and register my own blueprint with multiple urls that overrides args passed to dashboard.
But is there way to pass multiple Redis connection urls as arguments or something else **without forking repo**?

items.title: Display which localhost port is used on startup
items.body:
Currently I see this after I start `rq-dashboard`:

```RQ Dashboard version 0.5.3
 * Serving Flask app "rq_dashboard.cli" (lazy loading)
 * Environment: development
 * Debug mode: off
```

I don't have the default port number in my head, so it would be helpful to see at which address I can see the dashboard.

items.title: UI: Workers list goes off side of layout
items.body:
The main content is very narrow on the page and this causes the workers list to go off the side of the container.

![rq dashboard](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1611345/67817063-d93c8900-faf7-11e9-9d17-d720eb94e3ed.png)

items.title: UI: Large number of queues pushes content too far down
items.body:
Queues render at the top of the page with no option to collapse. I've got about 1200 queues and it pushes the actual page content really far down.

This can be confusing for other people in my team when I tell them to check rq-dashboard and they don't know the content they're after is actually at the bottom of the page.


items.title: New release to pick up recent fix
items.body: I'm hitting an issue that's solved by https://github.com/eoranged/rq-dashboard/commit/b603f118b77818afb8db64922ff680ffa39c0db7. Was wondering if we could get a minor release that includes that fix. I can't downgrade to before the issue was introduced since it was part of the 0.5.0 release which also added support for rq 1.0

items.title: Order in failed jobs is wrong
items.body:
-Currently failed jobs order is incorrect. It is sorted by queue.

Say we have three queue, high, low, default.

Failed jobs shows on the UI are currently in below order 

- all sorted `high` jobs
- all sorted `low` jobs
- all sorted `default` jobs

But it should be sorted globally.
sorted([jobs in low, high, default])

I have the following config:

```python
class BaseConfiguration(object):
    """Class with common configuration variables"""
    # ...

    # RQ settings
    REDIS_URL = 'redis://redis:6379/0'
    RQ_POLL_INTERVAL = 2500  #: Web interface poll period for updates in ms
```

items.title: What about having a running job view per queue
items.body:
Proposal to have a view that shows currently running jobs. 

- Job can be canceled or deleted
- Can stop all jobs via button click

items.title: Hide worker list by default
items.body: - Currently workers list can be hidden by toggle button. When we have workers more then 50 it creates a long right container and pushes the job list way down. What about hiding worker list by default and clicking `toggle` button will show it ?

items.title: List all contributors in AUTHORS file
items.body:
Two sections:
1. Maintainers (in alphabetical order)
2. Contributors (in alphabetical order).

items.title: Drop support for Python 3.4 and 2.7
items.body: We don't actually need to support all Python versions RQ does, so It's worth dropping support for old 3.x versions and probably 2.7 after LTS release.

items.title: get_failed_queue() function has been removed. Please use FailedJobRegistry(queue=queue) instead.
items.body:
python rq removed this functionality so rq-dashboard crashes
get_failed_queue() function has been removed. Please use FailedJobRegistry(queue=queue) instead.

items.title: Redis ssl cert handling
items.body:
Hi,

I've really enjoyed using rq-dashboard but I'm having issues using it with redis connections that require specific ssl configuration (related to the `ssl=False, ssl_keyfile=None, ssl_certfile=None, ssl_cert_reqs=u'required', ssl_ca_certs=None` parameters in https://redis-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#redis.Redis ).

For my particular case, I would like to be able to set `ssl_cert_reqs=None` as a parameter to the Redis object created in https://github.com/eoranged/rq-dashboard/blob/master/rq_dashboard/web.py#L41.

Is there already a way for me to do this, or would it possible to add this as a command line parameter or some kind of config file parameter?

Thanks for the help

items.title: Doesnt work in production server
items.body:
I added rq-dashboard to my production flask app, but nothing work. 
```
import rq_dashboard
app = Flask(__name__)
app.config.from_object(rq_dashboard.default_settings)
app.register_blueprint(rq_dashboard.blueprint, url_prefix="/rq")
```
and then go to the **myIP:5000/rq**

If I did same thing at my local app - all working well. Could you help me?

items.title: Username/password safety issue
items.body:
Hi,

Currently the username/password are provided explicitly from the command line, which makes the credentials visible to other users on the system. They can see by checking ‘ps -ef | grep rq-dashboard’

There are two ways to improve the security hazards:

1. Using a config file with username/password
2. Reading the pre-defined system variables directly from two-dashboard. 

Either options is easy to implement but greatly improved the security. If possible, I hope this can be done before version 1.0 is released

items.title: Upcoming release of RQ 1.0
items.body:
Hey there, just want to give a heads up about the next major RQ release, v1.0. I plan on releasing this new version in the second half of Feb (although this may change due to work commitments).

This release will have a few backward incompatible changes, the biggest one is the introduction of `FailedJobRegistry` that replaces `FailedQueue`. I have documented the new registry [here](https://github.com/rq/rq/blob/v1.0/docs/docs/jobs.md#failed-jobs).

The branch for the upcoming release is here: https://github.com/rq/rq/tree/v1.0
You may also find the changelog helpful: https://github.com/rq/rq/blob/v1.0/CHANGES.md

Let me know if there's any questions. Thanks!

items.title: Jobs list is empty but Worker is working
items.body: That all right. sorry. need was read documents

items.title: The table ui will break if long name
Docker image: 404 when requesting data
items.body:
If I build the Docker image and run it, the dashboard loads fine, but it doesn't load any data.

Using this minimal docker-compose.yml file:

```yaml
version: '3'

volumes:
  redis-data:

services:
  redis:
    image: redis:alpine
    volumes:
      - redis-data:/var/lib/redis
    restart: always
    ports:
      - "6380:6379"

  dashboard:
    build: .
    ports:
      - "8080:80"

    depends_on:
      - redis
```

... you can see that all the data endpoints return 404s for some reason:

```
$ docker-compose up
...
dashboard_1  | RQ Dashboard version 0.3.12
dashboard_1  |  * Running on http://0.0.0.0:80/ (Press CTRL+C to quit)
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:51] "GET / HTTP/1.1" 200 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:52] "GET /rq-instances.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:52] "GET /queues.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:52] "GET /workers.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:52] "GET /jobs/default/1.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:54] "GET /queues.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:54] "GET /workers.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:54] "GET /jobs/default/1.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:57] "GET /queues.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:57] "GET /workers.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [28/Aug/2018 15:59:57] "GET /jobs/default/1.json HTTP/1.1" 404 -
```

items.title: Release 0.3.12
items.body:
Hi @eoranged

We are using forked version of rq-dashboard in our project because of the `tests` confliction.
Would you please release a new version including #158 ?

items.title: pip install rq_dashboard includes tests in package top level
items.body:
We are trying to use rq-dashboard on our project.
But our unittests are failed after rq-dashboard installation.
It seems rq-dashboard's setup.py  creates tests directory.

```sh
$ pip install rq-dashboard
$ ls -1 .venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tests # => exists
```

It also has tests in top_level.txt.

```txt
rq_dashboard
tests
```

This should be removed.

items.title: Job is not cancelled when clicking on cancel
items.body:
Hi.

I have some failed jobs in the fail queue. I want to cancel them (not all of them though), but when I click on `cancel`, the job just reappears. I can see that the dashboard is sending e.g.:

```
rq-dashboard_1  | 172.18.0.1 - - [18/Apr/2018 07:52:14] "POST /job/0c4061e3-e1c9-4408-9295-f84b4af13f5b/cancel HTTP/1.1" 200 -
```

and the job disappears for few seconds, but then it's again in the failed queue.  I believe it's because it's considered as failed when being canceled? 

When I click on empty  to clear all jobs, it works as expected.

Is there any way how to avoid this? Isn't this actually a bug?

items.title: Release 0.3.11?
items.body:
Hi @eoranged ,

We've using for a few months the master branch as no new releases were done with the latests patches. Does it make sense to create a new release?

Thanks,

items.title: Enable password when integrate with existing flask app.
items.body:
This tool provides the ability to be integrated with an existing tool, as shown at the docs.

```
app = Flask(__name__)
app.config.from_object(rq_dashboard.default_settings)
app.register_blueprint(rq_dashboard.blueprint, url_prefix="/rq")
```

Although if I use this feature the dashboard runs as public route. It would be great If it had an option to override it's authentication with our own authentication route or provide the user and password anyhow.

items.title: Set logging settings for cli execution.
items.body: The ability to provide log settings like level or silent mode on cli.

items.title: UI redisign
items.body:
There are crunches being made to make existing dashboard look better, but It still not comfortable to use in most real-life scenarios.
Need to think of UX concept and implement It.
It is also seems reasonable to switch to Vue.js or React.

items.title: Drop Python 2.6 support
items.body:
From [PEP 361](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0361/#release-lifespan):
Python 2.6.9 is the final security-only source-only maintenance release of the Python 2.6 series. With its release on October 29, 2013, all official support for Python 2.6 has ended. Python 2.6 is no longer being maintained for any purpose.

items.title: Mabye move rq-dashboard to the rq organisation
items.body:
rq has now moved to an organisation https://github.com/rq.

Would you consider moving `rq-dashboard` into that organisation? Obviously all collaborators can become collaborators on the organisation.

items.title: Require confirmation before mass operations
items.body: For operations like "Requeue all", "Compact" and especially "Empty"

items.title: Redis Sentinel support
items.body: Since I could not find it in documentation, nor in code, just want to note that it would be really nice to have it.

items.title: Bump version
items.body:
Is it possible to bump the version to get the commit https://github.com/eoranged/rq-dashboard/commit/64685d9b4d901eba596b0dd2881d1aab7f0cd7e5 available from pip? 

thanks

items.title: Job data is downloaded but not all of it is used
items.body:
I noticed that when the serialized form of some job parameters is rather long (in the order of a couple megabytes), rq-dashboard performs very poorly, sometimes not even showing the list of jobs in a queue.

I found out that the reason for this is that there isn't enough time to download this large amount of data either between page refreshes, or before the job is popped from the queue, resulting in a "Broken Pipe" error. If the Redis server under RQ runs on AWS, and I start rq-dashboard locally, that is. If the Redis server is also running locally, there is no issue of course.

I know that passing this much data as function parameters might be a bit of abuse to RQ, but it is done in the name of simplicity - to be presented in a tutorial. And it works quite well in itself, just the dashboard has problems.

Perhaps downloading the job data could be avoided by not reconstructing the whole Job object locally, just fetching some info about it, which is enough to construct the appropriate REST response, and the displayed list.

The same thing applies to the results, as that can be large as well in my case.

items.title: Black background is akward
items.body:
This is nitpicking, but the total black background is kinda bad.

I'd love to see some other (gray?) background (either by default, or as an option).

items.title: Collapse workers list
items.body:
I have hundreds of workers, which results in a pretty long list on the right side.
This means when I want too look at my jobs in a queue I have to scroll all the way down.

It would be nice to auto-collapse the workers list, or move them to a different tab or pane.

items.title: Support multiple RQ instances
items.body:
Hello,

I'll open a PullRequest which adds support for multiple RQ instances.

When using the Flask Blueprint, it is possible to pass an array of Redis URL to the rq-dashboard plugin.

```python
app.config.update(REDIS_URL=['redis://localhost:6379/0', 'redis://localhost:6379/1'])
app.register_blueprint(rq_dashboard.blueprint, url_prefix='/rq')
```

When passing an array of connections, it will appear on the dashboard a new block with a dropdown, which lets changing the RQ instance to be observed.

![screen shot 2017-08-21 at 18 59 33](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2593956/29530199-eacc7868-86a2-11e7-8023-ce7ef1f39a27.png)

By default, rq-dashboard will show the information of the first RQ, but selecting another one, will trigger a swap on the backend, so it will start showing the new rq-instance data.

items.title: Difficulty copying and pasting text
items.body:
It's difficult to copy and paste text from rq-dashboard (on at least Chromium) because the selection is lost after just a few seconds (even if you haven't finished selecting the text).

This may be related to how the dashboard updates itself automatically.

items.title: pip install fails: No matching distribution found for rq-dashboard==0.3.8
items.body:
### Issue:

pip install fails because couldn't find the package:
`No matching distribution found for rq-dashboard==0.3.8`

### how to reproduce the error:
1.  `mkvirtualenv test_rq`
2. by default it will use python 2.7.x
3. `pip install rq-dashboard==0.3.8`
4. Error raised: 
```
$ pip install rq-dashboard==0.3.8
Collecting rq-dashboard==0.3.8
  Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement rq-dashboard==0.3.8 (from versions: 0.1.0, 0.2, 0.3, 0.3.1, 0.3.2, 0.3.3, 0.3.4, 0.3.5, 0.3.6, 0.3.7)
No matching distribution found for rq-dashboard==0.3.8
```

items.title: RQ-Dashboard on Heroku not loading REDIS_URL
items.body:
I have installed RQ-Dashboard onto my Flask application, and have a page that prints out the `REDIS_URL` variable from my environment configuration.

Testing application locally with both `localhost:6379` and my actual Heroku Redis url `redis://h:password@host:port` works; the HTML prints out `REDIS_URL` settings correctly, the dashboard shows the worker statuses correctly, and I am able to queue workers, etc. etc.

Moving the application onto Heroku results in a HTTP500 Internal Server error when accessing the dashboard url.

Looking at the application logs results in:
`ConnectionError: Error 111 connecting to localhost:6379. Connection refused.`

If it was a problem with the `REDIS_URL` setting on Heroku I would have expected the HTML print out to be NONE and also not able to queue any jobs. But the print out gives the expected value and I can still queue and process jobs. 

I am on 0.3.7 of rq-dashboard and 0.7.1 of rq. Thoughts appreciated, thanks.

items.title: 0.3.8 not on pypy
jobs always say "Failed 4 hours ago" with None listed as caught Error
items.body:
In my default queue this information always shows up, even if the job is only 1-5 seconds old. My guess is that it shouldn't be if the job hasn't run yet and is in the default queue.

Data shows up correctly in the regular queue.

Not sure if it matters but setup is python 2.7, flask, rq-scheduler, and this.

items.title: UI too slow to load or hangs when jobs with long descriptions are queued
items.body:
First of all, I really appreciate your work on rq-dashboard! I find it very useful and use it almost everyday. There is one small problem, however, which makes the dashboard hard to use in some cases.

When I have RQ jobs queued with very long descriptions (e.g. a function call with a list argument containing 1000s of elements), the UI takes a _very_ long time to load or simply hangs. I do **this** to get around the issue at the moment: https://github.com/ducu/rq-dashboard/pull/109 (limiting the number of characters to 100 by default and giving the user control over it via a new command line option). The PR is probably a little too hacky to merge but I think some sort of control over the number of characters coming from the RQ jobs is definitely needed. Please take a look.

Thanks a bunch!
Joohwan

items.title: rq-dashboard not displaying correctly under https
items.body: I'm trying to use the rq dashboard via my flask app.  But it doesn't display correctly never loads any of the information.  But if I run it through the port with no https it works fine

items.body: I can bring up the dashboard and it looks great.  It tells me I have 101 failed jobs.  But when i click on the failed "queue", nothing is listed.  Am I doing something wrong?

items.title: when integrating with Flask, specify the url_prefix
items.body:
When integrating with my own Flask app, 

```
app.register_blueprint(rq_dashboard.blueprint)
```

returns a page, but I can see lots of 404s in the background, and I get no useful data on the page. Changing the setup to be:

```
app.register_blueprint(rq_dashboard.blueprint, url_prefix="/rq")
```

Does let me see everything.

items.title: SyntaxError in 0.3.5+ under Python 2.6.6
items.body:
I'm running rq-dashboard under Python 2.6.6, and I noticed in 0.3.5, [this line](https://github.com/nvie/rq-dashboard/blob/14527acecfc0c2be0c5bcc2812189da2b5f82bd6/rq_dashboard/web.py#L105) was introduced which throws a SyntaxError. Is there any chance of a more backwards-compatible version?

Thanks so much!

items.title: simplejson required ?
items.body:
Hello,

The simplejson module seems to be required to make the dashboard work properly.
When not having it installed, the request that gets the worker list fails with this message (it occurs when the dashboard is loaded in a browser) :

```
127.0.0.1 - - [26/Jan/2016 15:16:43] "GET /myapi/monitor/workers.json HTTP/1.1" 500 -

  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/json/encoder.py", line 173, in default
    raise TypeError(repr(o) + " is not JSON serializable")
TypeError: b'idle' is not JSON serializable
```

Note that I use the dashboard inside my own flask application :

```
# Load app config
conf = json.load(open('conf/api-conf.json'))

# Init controller routes manager
# Generate the monitor queues view
try:
    from rq_dashboard import cli
    app = cli.make_flask_app(None, None, None, url_prefix='/' + conf['url_prefix'] + '/monitor')
except Exception as e:
    logger.error("Can't create the view for redis queue monitoring")
    app = Flask(__name__)

# Message file for dealing with asynchronous jobs
redis_con = Redis(conf['redis']['host'], conf['redis']['port'])
job_queue = Queue(conf['redis']['jobs_queue'], connection=redis_con)
success_queue = Queue('janus_ok', connection=redis_con)

# Load app config into Flask WSGI running instance
app.config['API_CONF'] = conf
app.config['PROPAGATE_EXCEPTIONS'] = True
app.config['REDIS_QUEUE_KEY'] = conf['redis']['jobs_queue']

app.config['REDIS_HOST'] = conf['redis']['host']
app.config['REDIS_PORT'] = conf['redis']['port']
```

Here is the complete stacktrace error :

```
127.0.0.1 - - [26/Jan/2016 15:16:43] "GET /myapi/monitor/workers.json HTTP/1.1" 500 -
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1836, in __call__
    return self.wsgi_app(environ, start_response)
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1820, in wsgi_app
    response = self.make_response(self.handle_exception(e))
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask_restful/__init__.py", line 271, in error_router
    return original_handler(e)
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask_cors/__init__.py", line 279, in wrapped_function
    return cors_after_request(app.make_response(f(*args, **kwargs)))
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1403, in handle_exception
    reraise(exc_type, exc_value, tb)
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask/_compat.py", line 33, in reraise
    raise value
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1817, in wsgi_app
    response = self.full_dispatch_request()
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1477, in full_dispatch_request
    rv = self.handle_user_exception(e)
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask_restful/__init__.py", line 271, in error_router
    return original_handler(e)
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask_cors/__init__.py", line 279, in wrapped_function
    return cors_after_request(app.make_response(f(*args, **kwargs)))
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1381, in handle_user_exception
    reraise(exc_type, exc_value, tb)
  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask/_compat.py", line 33, in reraise

  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/rq_dashboard/web.py", line 72, in _wrapped

  File "/home/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/p3.4_janus/lib/python3.4/site-packages/flask/json.py", line 238, in jsonify
```

To make it works, I just install the simplejson module :

```
> pip install simplejson
```

Hope it'll help and thanks for all the job !!!

Fabrice

items.title: Turn off request logging?
items.body:
When you run rq-dashboard, it prints every GET request to stderr.

This is certainly useful for debugging rq-dashboard itself, but it's not really helpful when running a stable version of rq-dashboard for some other purpose.

I wish there were a way, externally to rq-dashboard, to make it silent except when there's an error.

items.title: Dashboard Page Load Issue
items.body: I have the dashbaord and everything up and running under supervisor and it works great. The issue is, after a few days of running when I go to the dashboard end point, the page doesn't load, doesn't time out, and just sits there with the browsers info message at the bottom saying waiting on end point. I've hopped onto the box and did the command line queries and all the workers are up and running just fine. Supervisor even says everything is working dandy as well. It seems the dashboard is just tanking and nothing else is really having an issue.

items.title: Version on pip is not current
items.body:
I'm using python 2.7, and when I tried integrating this with an existing flask app, I got the error:

```
    application.config.from_object(rq_dashboard.default_settings)
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'default_settings'
```

items.title: Serious lag issues
items.body: I used rq for handling a queueing system for video rendering in our system. I have about 289 workers from other computers checking into the main controller. Before I ran any jobs through rq-dashboard worked just fine but once I pushed around 112k videos through it, the dashboard just tanked. Even after all the jobs went through the system (rq is a bit of a beast) the dashboard still had issues. Finally after starting and stopping and after a reboot of the system the dashboard finally came back up.

items.title: Crash when lazy initialise with flask app
items.body:
I was trying to integrate rq-dashboard into my flask app, with the following lines:

```
from rq_dashboard import RQDashboard
dashboard = RQDashboard()                    # crash here!!
```

then initialise the app from `create_app` function:

```
dashboard.init_app(app)
```

However, it crash immediately on creation. I believe this has been fixed with commit: https://github.com/nvie/rq-dashboard/commit/84b9cf244ca5327c3a99107d13e69b7613f73d64 

My question is, when are you going to release this piece of code that fixed 8 months ago?


items.title: not retuen json when get fail jobs
items.body:
``` [root@master rq-dashboard]# curl -v "http://127.0.0.1:9181//jobs/failed/1.json" * About to connect() to 127.0.0.1 port 9181 (#0) * Trying 127.0.0.1... connected * Connected to 127.0.0.1 (127.0.0.1) port 9181 (#0) > GET //jobs/failed/1.json HTTP/1.1 > User-Agent: curl/7.19.7 (x86_64-redhat-linux-gnu) libcurl/7.19.7 NSS/3.13.1.0 zlib/1.2.3 libidn/1.18 libssh2/1.2.2 > Host: 127.0.0.1:9181 > Accept: */* > * Closing connection #0 * Failure when receiving data from the peer curl: (56) Failure when receiving data from the peer [root@master rq-dashboard]# curl -v "http://127.0.0.1:9181//jobs/failed/1.json" * About to connect() to 127.0.0.1 port 9181 (#0) * Trying 127.0.0.1... connected * Connected to 127.0.0.1 (127.0.0.1) port 9181 (#0) > GET //jobs/failed/1.json HTTP/1.1 > User-Agent: curl/7.19.7 (x86_64-redhat-linux-gnu) libcurl/7.19.7 NSS/3.13.1.0 zlib/1.2.3 libidn/1.18 libssh2/1.2.2 > Host: 127.0.0.1:9181 > Accept: */* > * HTTP 1.0, assume close after body < HTTP/1.0 200 OK < Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8 < Content-Length: 16407 < Server: Werkzeug/0.9.4 Python/2.6.6 < Date: Fri, 25 Apr 2014 16:11:32 GMT < RQ dashboard

Queues

This list below contains all the registered queues with the number of jobs currently in the queue. Select a queue from above to view all jobs currently pending on the queue.
